summary: Don addresses the gap between public expectations and school delivery, citing Common Core State Standards and Ontario's Provincial Report Card as incomplete responses. title: 500 Teachers as Change Agents
summary: Don defines teachers as change agents helping learners acquire behaviors for adult community participation, arguing content is the easy part. Learning, he states, is change—in cognitive, affective, or psychomotor domains. Learning is fundamentally individual; teachers don't teach classes but may teach multiple individuals within group settings. Teaching involves stimulating learning through diverse techniques: modeling, information delivery, questioning, timelines, projects, field trips, and assessment. The crux of good teaching is creating individual learning environments that yield favorable experiences. Don notes subjects serve as media for teaching broader skills—English teaches communication, school environment teaches citizenship. Good assessment focuses on what people actually do in real life: communicate, solve problems, discuss literature, analyze situations, not on memorizing isolated content.

summary: Open Education No. 63 (April 18, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning questioning whether current school calendars can coexist with learning excellence. He notes individual learner pace and style differences conflict with group-based instruction organized in time blocks, complicating diploma awards and graduation ceremonies. title: 94 Learning
summary: Don presents his philosophy of learning as personal, multi-faceted change in how people think, feel, and act. He stresses that learners carry three types of baggage into learning situations: innate conditions, prior learning, and aspirations about the future. Criticizing PEI's narrow focus on school-based education, he argues institutions must redesign programs to accommodate diverse learner needs and that educators must engage as professionals with communities they serve, not remain confined by political filters and bureaucratic constraints. His vision emphasizes that meaningful education develops lifelong competencies beyond credentialing.
